reviewText:
“Stellar 2D is a retro style space arcade game, it's a 2D game in a 3D world. With an addictive, fast paced, casual game-play style.”

This quote has some truth to it, but also some lies. Stellar 2D is a retro style space arcade game but it is NOT addictive. In fact, this game seems quite incomplete and quite bad at the moment. HOWEVER, there is some potential buried deep within Stellar 2D. The overall idea isn’t bad or original. It’s basically a bullet hell, casual space arcade game. Sounds like a fun game right? WRONG! Currently there are SO many problems that Stellar 2D isn’t fun.

-Random status effects prevent horizontal or vertical movement.
Like WTF! These effects are the most annoying part about Stellar 2D. These so called “power-ups” make this game unbearable.

-Virtually invisible bullets
These “bullets” (I use that term loosely) are practically invisible 99% of the time. It makes this game not fun and just bad, unless the idea was that in the future bullets (all except you’re bullets) are undetectable.

-Game’s Menu / HUD
Do NOT get me started about this menu or HUD. Although the developer had fixed SOME issues, it’s still s*** and visually unappealing. Like what’s up with the font?

-Graphics
The game’s graphics are s*** at best. The opening cut scene’s graphics was the worst that I’ve ever seen in a game…EVER! It’s just not good.

-Sound Effects
Gave me permanent, PERMANENT hearing damage, 11 / 10.

-Space Crafts
Many appear to be unoriginal and copied.

What also “bugs” me about Stellar 2D is that there are STILL bugs (see what I did there) in this game, mainly with the menu. On August 5th 2015, I launched Stellar 2D to find the audio disappeared the moment I clicked on the menu. Although (for this game) no sound is better than sound…this shouldn’t happen. Now I know the developers did fix some issues but still, COME ON! This would be understandable if this game was in early access, but it’s not!

My final comments on this game are, I’m glad I got it for $.15. At this stage, it’s really, REALLY not worth purchasing. However, I like the idea. If the developers can fix this game up then I’ll gladly change my review from negative to positive.

I really hope that this game will eventually meet my standards but as of now…it’s just painful.

-Mr_Kagabond

reviewText:
As much as I like 2-D shoot ‘em ups, there isn’t much good I can say about Stellar 2D.

This game has potential to become a decent 2-D shooter, except the gameplay constantly works against you while playing the game. The ship is fairly hard to control in contrast to most 2-D shooters out there. Pressing up and left while shooting will cause the ship to ignore your input, making it harder to maneuver around enemy projectiles. Some of the bullets are difficult to see, particularly the linear bullets that are mildly faded. It’s not too big of problem, but I’ve died so many times not knowing what just hit my ship until the last second. The biggest problem I have with the enemy bullets is the sound it makes when the enemy ship fires one. The default audio level of the sound effect greatly contrasts the default audio level of the background music and you will constantly hear the same few sound effects every second. The red, blue, and green sphere thingy (Note: I don’t know its official name) is the most annoying mechanic in the game for me. Basically, its risk versus reward. You can either get a speed boost, power boost, or one of the major debuffs the game has to offer. These debuffs occur way more than it should and it destroys any chance you have at surviving. These debuffs include: no horizontal movement, no vertical movement, having your ship slow down, and worst of all, the inability to shoot. The inability to shoot not only allows you to become more susceptible to damage, it also hinders your progress towards making it to the next level. Finally, the bosses are a joke. No really, they only exist to randomly show up and die in less than three seconds.

As much as the bad stuff outweighs the good with this game, some of the good ideas this game has seems faintly innovative. I like the leniency of this game. The amount of HP it gives, the shield mechanic, and the rate the health packs spawns lends the game to a more casual audience. The amount of health the enemies have, make the gameplay fast-paced and mildly amusing compared to the average shoot ‘em up. The range upgrades makes the game somewhat enjoyable for me. Having an edge over your enemies when using this upgrade is satisfying to say the least. If I could say anything bad about it, it’s that you’re not able to pick up a better range upgrade until your current one runs out. That and the fact you can only keep it for a limited amount of time.

Overall, the game felt unsatisfying. With a decent idea, bad gameplay, and that unskippable logo sequence, I would recommend getting it only for the trading cards.

At any rate, if you buy at this price, the cards are worth more than the game, and you profit.
Still might be fun at other times, at very least to distract your six-year-old for a while. Or yourself, if your lifestyle is plain and your tastes are simple. Don't expect X-Wing vs. TIE Fighter or anything. Think old arcade, last century kind.
My only real complaints are the following: debuffs last WAY too long, graphics at different resolutions in windowed mode cause it to clip through the taskbar and things, and invisible cursor in menu screens. Oh yeah, and the window still responds when it is minimised. Other than that, here's how it is: gameplay is indeed fast paced as per the description, navigation is limited to moving and shooting, and everything has healthbars. There's an intro sequence, but I don't think there's an end to this game. That's probably a minus in itself, but it doesn't take away from general gameplay. Graphics are remarkably good for an arcade game, except for the fact that your ship doesn't disappear after exploding. That's probably bug, but it's amusing to watch. I approve. You ran out of health, fire-cloud, and your ship keeps sailing on like nothing until the world resets a second or so later. On another note, if you are one of those people with little to no sense of humour and high expectations of a game, keep away from this one unless you're a masochist, in which case you should keep your money and go get help because you need it REALLY badly.

reviewText:
I only felt the need to write a review because of all the people hating on this game. Not that I'm going to come out swinging in an attempt to defend it as it definitely has issues, but it has also been out for all of four days as of this post. Four days and the dev is already admitting to making some mistakes (start menu locking up and making the game unplayable) and better yet, taking steps to fix them. How many triple-A titles are chock full of bugs at launch requiring patches for the next few weeks? Pretty much every WoW xpac comes to mind among many other titles. I'm guessing that's forgivable because it's a big name developer, right? The game is a DOLLAR at base price... I work a minimum wage job part-time and find nearly that much in loose change on the floor when I sweep at night, how is anyone complaining about anything in this game? Especially since it's on sale for thirteen cents... that's not sitting between the cushions in your couch? It's far too loud, yes. Turn your system/headphone/speaker/whatever volume down if the in-game volume controls don't work. Game.exe seems weird? Really? Should they have named it stellar2d.exe instead? Do you remember any of the older games that started up in DOS as ______.exe and sat there while command lines popped up until it had finished doing its thing and the game finally started? There's more that I'd bash on but I'll just get to the review.

~~~~~~~

The game is quite simply a very low-end indie version of any side-scrolling shoorter you've ever played and this is visible in pretty much every aspect of the game. It seems very similar to the old shooters I played as a kid in the local arcade, R-Type for instance, though much less polished.

I can't comment on the Config window that pops up after launching the game as I set it to what I felt should be right the first time and never messed with it again and I don't play with a joystick, WASD works great.

The main menu is uncomplicated and features the usual selections though the sliders in Options are more difficult to manipulate than they should be while the font throughout the game is perhaps too stylized and the navigation arrows in some places aren't immediately obvious (the ones in the ship select screen particularly) and need some sort of contrasting border or perhaps not be neon blue. The Credits page (did anyone even bother checking that out?) points out just how much of an indie title this is, six people. That's counting the gal at the end who was responsible for the social media end of things and not credited with any sort of development. Something else I noticed, they're all the type of photos you'd see on someone's facebook page (except for David Webb's, totally lives in an 80s sitcom... ) My point is these are just a few people, probably all friends, who wanted to make something and share it with us.


As for gameplay, it's actually kinda challenging, for me at least, and it gets very frantic further in but is fun in its own way. I think the gameplay elements need to be a bit more clear, like the swirling blue cloud that starts to chase your ship around... what is it? It'd be cool if hitting a new power-up either reset the timer on your current one (assuming they're the same) or swapped to the new one. I feel that the traps, debuffs basically, are a bit too powerful or unclear. For instance the vertical/horizontal freezes and no shooting, they last far too long in my opinion. The no shooting one especially, that basically ends the game as the screen is swarmed with enemy ships long before it wears off.

There needs to be a cursor for menu navigation or have mouse movements change what items are selected as with tabbing through clickable things in a window. Just seems weird that you have to navigate with an invisible cusor.

The intro movie made me facepalm, I just... that voice, it's a good try though.

The ship designs for the most part are very interesting and I feel sensical in many cases. I'll probably use some of them as ideas for Space Engineers or my own artwork.

I love most of the backgrounds and in fact I'd have paid a dollar for a game that was simply dodging asteroids with high-res versions of the images used for the backgrounds (total space nut) though I'm not sure how I feel about images that are obviously from other games like seeing the Normandy from Mass Effect.

The music is kinda nice and if they released a twenty-five or even fifty cent DLC of the soundtrack I'd probably snag that too if the tracks were at least a few minutes long each or all mixed together to make a long-ish track that looped well.

I think the general backlash from many of the commenters could have been avoided if the game had been released as Early Access and therefore obviously a WiP and as it stands right now I think that's the only way this should even be on Steam since it is far from completed (glaring typo on the main screen for instance unless that's supposed to be Star since the game is Stellar 2D, stellar-star... har har?) But that also means that if they plan to do more with it such as general improvements maybe there will be more modes like a zen type mode with relaxing music or a super swarm mode featuring default gameplay but with a bazillion debuffs that last a fraction of a second just to mess with you...


Overall I can't sit and play for hours straight and I doubt this game will get more than a few hours of play total but for the price it's well worth it. It needs a ton of work but it's a decent attempt at producing a simple game so it gets a 3 or 4 out of 10 for execution but I'd add a point for the attempt and at the non-sale price of a buck, it gets another point or two for value so say an even 6/10. I definitely don't feel that I was ripped off, even if the developer made no more changes to the game and left it as is, it is playable and mildly entertaining. Not a bad way to kill ten or fifteen minutes before heading out the door. Recommended if for no other reason than as encouragement to an indie developer to try again.

~~~~~~~

tl:dr
♥♥♥♥ off with the negativity about the problems in a thirteen cent game made by a small group of friends who have lives outside of game development. Uhg, people.

Turn your system/headphone/speaker/whatever volume down if the in-game volume controls don't work. Game.exe seems weird? Really? Should they have named it stellar2d.exe instead? Do you remember any of the older games that started up in DOS as ______.exe and sat there while command lines popped up until it had finished doing its thing and the game finally started? There's more that I'd bash on but I'll just get to the review.

~~~~~~~

The game is quite simply a very low-end indie version of any side-scrolling shoorter you've ever played and this is visible in pretty much every aspect of the game. It seems very similar to the old shooters I played as a kid in the local arcade, R-Type for instance, though much less polished.

I can't comment on the Config window that pops up after launching the game as I set it to what I felt should be right the first time and never messed with it again and I don't play with a joystick, WASD works great.

The main menu is uncomplicated and features the usual selections though the sliders in Options are more difficult to manipulate than they should be while the font throughout the game is perhaps too stylized and the navigation arrows in some places aren't immediately obvious (the ones in the ship select screen particularly) and need some sort of contrasting border or perhaps not be neon blue. The Credits page (did anyone even bother checking that out?) points out just how much of an indie title this is, six people. That's counting the gal at the end who was responsible for the social media end of things and not credited with any sort of development. Something else I noticed, they're all the type of photos you'd see on someone's facebook page (except for David Webb's, totally lives in an 80s sitcom... ) My point is these are just a few people, probably all friends, who wanted to make something and share it with us.


As for gameplay, it's actually kinda challenging, for me at least, and it gets very frantic further in but is fun in its own way. I think the gameplay elements need to be a bit more clear, like the swirling blue cloud that starts to chase your ship around... what is it? It'd be cool if hitting a new power-up either reset the timer on your current one (assuming they're the same) or swapped to the new one. I feel that the traps, debuffs basically, are a bit too powerful or unclear. For instance the vertical/horizontal freezes and no shooting, they last far too long in my opinion. The no shooting one especially, that basically ends the game as the screen is swarmed with enemy ships long before it wears off.

There needs to be a cursor for menu navigation or have mouse movements change what items are selected as with tabbing through clickable things in a window. Just seems weird that you have to navigate with an invisible cusor.

The intro movie made me facepalm, I just... that voice, it's a good try though.

The ship designs for the most part are very interesting and I feel sensical in many cases. I'll probably use some of them as ideas for Space Engineers or my own artwork.

I love most of the backgrounds and in fact I'd have paid a dollar for a game that was simply dodging asteroids with high-res versions of the images used for the backgrounds (total space nut) though I'm not sure how I feel about images that are obviously from other games like seeing the Normandy from Mass Effect.

The music is kinda nice and if they released a twenty-five or even fifty cent DLC of the soundtrack I'd probably snag that too if the tracks were at least a few minutes long each or all mixed together to make a long-ish track that looped well.

I think the general backlash from many of the commenters could have been avoided if the game had been released as Early Access and therefore obviously a WiP and as it stands right now I think that's the only way this should even be on Steam since it is far from completed (glaring typo on the main screen for instance unless that's supposed to be Star since the game is Stellar 2D, stellar-star... har har?) But that also means that if they plan to do more with it such as general improvements maybe there will be more modes like a zen type mode with relaxing music or a super swarm mode featuring default gameplay but with a bazillion debuffs that last a fraction of a second just to mess with you...


Overall I can't sit and play for hours straight and I doubt this game will get more than a few hours of play total but for the price it's well worth it. It needs a ton of work but it's a decent attempt at producing a simple game so it gets a 3 or 4 out of 10 for execution but I'd add a point for the attempt and at the non-sale price of a buck, it gets another point or two for value so say an even 6/10. I definitely don't feel that I was ripped off, even if the developer made no more changes to the game and left it as is, it is playable and mildly entertaining. Not a bad way to kill ten or fifteen minutes before heading out the door. Recommended if for no other reason than as encouragement to an indie developer to try again.

~~~~~~~

reviewText: Welcome to Stellar 2D, a game developed by a handful of independant developers sold typically for .99 on the Steam market (.15-.17 during major sales). To be honest I wasn't entirely aware of what to expect, when I purchased the game it was mostly due to its price tag; however, having bought this for .17 I think I got what I paid for. It was decent, but was fairly choppy, the movement had no animation what so ever, purely the model skirting across the screen. The background of the menu, storyline and loading screen all looked rather outdated; but again as I said I got what I paid for. The gameplay was decent, at times when jacked up on multiple power ups it was incredibly easy; however at other times it appeared to be much harder as the game progressed. There weren't any fixed power ups making the player not get any stronger as the game got harder, causing the player to get swarmed by enemy fire around 'Level 4'. My biggest pet peeve when it comes to this game is the enemy fire isn't represented by an accurate model, the models stretch across the screen 1-3 inches longer than the area that will actually cause damage which thwarts the player from effectively dodging fire. Despite a few outdated aspects and a slightly awkward gameplay, this was a decent reincarnation of the arcade game 'Stellar' and was probably worth the .17 I paid for it (in addition to the typical .99 fixed price); overall a nice mini-game.

reviewText: Welcome to Stellar 2D, a game developed by a handful of independant developers sold typically for .99 on the Steam market (.15-.17 during major sales). To be honest I wasn't entirely aware of what to expect, when I purchased the game it was mostly due to its price tag; however, having bought this for .17 I think I got what I paid for. It was decent, but was fairly choppy, the movement had no animation what so ever, purely the model skirting across the screen. The background of the menu, storyline and loading screen all looked rather outdated; but again as I said I got what I paid for. The gameplay was decent, at times when jacked up on multiple power ups it was incredibly easy; however at other times it appeared to be much harder as the game progressed. There weren't any fixed power ups making the player not get any stronger as the game got harder, causing the player to get swarmed by enemy fire around 'Level 4'. My biggest pet peeve when it comes to this game is the enemy fire isn't represented by an accurate model, the models stretch across the screen 1-3 inches longer than the area that will actually cause damage which thwarts the player from effectively dodging fire. Despite a few outdated aspects and a slightly awkward gameplay, this was a decent reincarnation of the arcade game 'Stellar' and was probably worth the .17 I paid for it (in addition to the typical .99 fixed price); overall a nice mini-game.
